title: How to Plant Gloriosa Bulbs

parts.name: Picking a Time and Location to Plant

steps.headline: Plant your bulbs in the late spring or early summer.
steps.description: Make sure the threat of frost has passed in your region before you plant your flowers. If you are afraid your region might get frost again, consider planting your bulbs in pots to keep them indoors. In warmer zones of the United States, like zones 8 through 10, gloriosa bulbs may be able to survive all year long. In colder zones, like 1 through 7, they need to be planted in the spring time after the threat of frost has passed.

steps.headline: Choose a spot that drains well.
steps.description: Take a look at the area you want to plant your bulbs and notice if it makes puddles after it rains. If it does, add 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of organic material, like peat moss or compost, on top of the soil to add drainage.Warning: All parts of the gloriosa lily are poisonous, so choose a spot away from animals and small children. Clay soil does not drain well, so you shouldn’t use it to plant your bulbs. If you are planting your bulbs in pots, choose medium potting soil and make sure your pots have holes in the bottom for drainage. Try planting your lilies with dill, marigolds, or geraniums. These plants have shallow roots, so they won’t interfere with your gloriosa bulbs.

steps.headline: Find an area that gets at least 8 hours of sun per day.
steps.description: South-facing areas usually get the most sunlight. Try to pick a place where your gloriosa bulbs can soak up the sun for the better part of the day.If you are keeping your bulbs indoors, place them in a south-facing window.

parts.name: Digging Holes and Planting Your Bulbs

steps.headline: Plant your bulbs in holes that are 3 to 4 inches (7.6 to 10.2 cm) deep.
steps.description: Use a gardening spade to hollow out areas of soil that are large enough for your bulbs. Set the bulbs into the holes on their sides, and try to handle the bulbs as little as possible to avoid damaging them. The bulbs will figure out which way is down by feeling the sun and orient their roots in the opposite way.

steps.headline: Space your bulbs 8 to 12 inches (20 to 30 cm) apart.
steps.description: As you plant each bulb, make sure they are spaced far enough apart so they aren’t encroaching on one another’s territory. It’s better to leave too much room in between each one than not enough.Tip: If you are planting your bulbs in pots, give each bulb its own 1 gallon (3.8 L) pot.

steps.headline: Add stakes to encourage vine growth near each bulb.
steps.description: Gather some thin, wooden or metal stakes and place them about 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) away from each bulb sticking upright. Pound them about 1 in (2.5 cm) into the dirt so that they stay standing up.You can find wooden stakes at most garden supply stores.

steps.headline: Soak the soil with water to settle the bulbs.
steps.description: Use a watering can or a hose to douse the the bulbs in about 1 in (2.5 cm) of water from your watering can, leaving the soil soaked. The water helps to squish the soil onto the bulbs and makes them root. Try not to let any water puddle up on top of the soil to preserve the freshness of the bulbs.

parts.name: Watering, Fertilizing, and Winterizing Your Bulbs

steps.headline: Water your bulbs once a week to keep the soil wet.
steps.description: Use a watering can or a hose to keep your bulbs wet. Give them about 1 in (2.5 cm) of water per week so they have a chance to soak it in, and try not to let water puddle on top of the soil.Tip: Watering once a week is better than every few days so that your bulbs don’t get waterlogged and rot.

steps.headline: Add a half-strength fertilizer every 2 weeks.
steps.description: Purchase a 20-20-20 fertilizer and mix 1 tsp (14 g) of it with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water. Pour the fertilizer mixture in a circle around each bulb, being careful not to disturb any sprouts if there are any. Fold the fertilizer into the soil with a small gardening rake to give your bulbs some added nutrients.You can purchase fertilizer at most gardening stores. Diluting your fertilizer lessens the likelihood of damaging buildup around your bulbs.

steps.headline: Remove weeds and cover roots to keep pests away.
steps.description: If any small weeds crop up around your bulbs as they sprout, gently pull them out by hand without disturbing the roots of your gloriosas. If you notice any disturbances around your bulbs from deer or squirrels, place some rocks over the roots of the bulbs to keep them out of reach.Since gloriosa lilies taste bad, most garden pests stay away from them.

steps.headline: Let yellowing leaves and flowers fall off naturally as they die.
steps.description: As the weather cools down in the fall, you may notice the foliage of your lilies turning different colors. Do not cut them off or tear them; instead, let them fall off naturally and incorporate them into the soil if you’d like to.Even as the foliage starts to die, it can still gather energy for the plant as it prepares for winter.

steps.headline: Dig up each bulb and place it in a bed of peat moss in the fall.
steps.description: Once the temperature falls below 40 °F (4 °C), use a gardening spade to carefully dig up your bulbs. Place them into a box full of slightly damp peat moss and store them in a cool, dry place for the duration of winter.Keeping your bulbs inside prevents them from dying in the cold temperatures. If your bulbs are in pots, you can leave them in their pots and keep them inside for the winter.

steps.headline: Replant the bulbs in the spring.
steps.description: Use the same planting techniques that you did last year to replant the bulbs in the same area. Add more fertilizer to the soil before you replant your bulbs to give them more nutrients in the spring. Depending on how old your bulbs are, you can make them flower annually for years to come.

Place them into a box full of slightly damp peat moss and store them in a cool, dry place for the duration of winter.Keeping your bulbs inside prevents them from dying in the cold temperatures.
